text:
LORDING OVER US: The cut price drinks and gourmet menu of the House of Lords REVEALED LORDING OVER US: The cut price drinks and gourmet menu of the House of Lords REVEALED WHEN the unelected £300-a-day peers of the House of Lords are not having the last say on the nation’s laws they are treated to gourmet silver service in opulent dining rooms, it has been revealed. PUBLISHED: 05:35, Sat, Feb 25, 2017 | UPDATED: 05:49, Sat, Feb 25, 2017 
The well-bred and well-fed modern-day aristocrats have their every whim catered for in what Liberal Democrat peer Lord Tyler calls ”best day care centre for the elderly in London”. 
In the regal dining rooms of the House, Lords and Ladies can tuck into chargrilled poussin, or Brixham Dover sole at £37 a plate. 
And when the unelected lawmakers are feeling parched they can whet their whistle with a pint of Carlsberg at £2.90 – significantly lower than prices elsewhere in central London. 
The dining rooms and bars are all subsidised by the taxpayer, despite peers pulling in a £300-a-day allowance for showing up to work. GETTY/BBC Lords and Ladies can tuck into chargrilled poussin, or Brixham Dover sole at £37 a plate Related articles Theresa May bares brunt of cruel BBC gags after appearing in Lords 
But while food and drinks are made cheaper by a taxpayer cash injection, the Lords are cutting down on the amount of public money used – from £1.34million last year to £1.2million in 2017. 
The fees paid out in attendance allowance make up another £19million hole in the pockets of the British people. 
The shocking indulgence of the Peers’ official dining rooms, revealed by a BBC fly-on-the-wall documentary, is on offer to members of the Upper house despite many not contributing to policy debates. 
Baroness Smith of Gilmorehill, who has claimed £220,000 of expenses over her 27 year career on the red benches, has never spoken in a debate. BBC The upper house offers many places for lawmakers to relax and recline A retrospect of the State Opening of Parliament Sat, July 2, 2016 A beautiful retrospect of the State Opening of Parliament in The House of Lords, Westminster from 1952. Popperfoto/Getty Images 1 of 27 1952: Jovial Queen Elizabeth having left Buckingham Palace in the Irish State coach for Westminster for the State Opening of Parliament 
And Baroness Falkender – a former private secretary to Prime Minister Harold Wilson – has not made a maiden speech in her 42 years since acquiring the title. 
It comes after members of the Lords insisted they had a right to fight a clean-break Brexit and even to try to keep Britain in the European Union. 
They completed a two-day Second Reading debate on the principles of the legislation to let the Prime Minister start formal talks with the EU by invoking Article 50 of the Lisbon Treaty. 
The brief EU (Notification of Withdrawal) Bill passed the Commons with no changes. BBC The Lords Dining room is manned by highly attentive waiting staff BBC Peers are paid a £300 allowance for turning up to work at the house 
But some of the more than 180 peers who spoke in the Lords first debate on it made clear they will try to amend it during more detailed scrutiny starting next week. 
Labour former minister Lord McKenzie of Luton conceded the elected Commons must prevail: "However, we should push our authority to the limit in challenging the Government on their proposed deal." 
Conservative former pensions minster Baroness Altmann said concerned peers had a duty despite the personal attacks rained down on them to speak out about the risks to ordinary people of a Brexit which put "politics above economics”. 
She added: “Of course the elected chamber has the final say… but the role of this chamber is to point out where legislation needs amending when we believe mistakes have been made.” Related articles
